Definition: In this task, you will receive public comments from online platforms. You are expected to divide the comment into two classes: identity attack and non-identity attack. Identity attack refers to anything that is rude or disrespectful to a person's identity, including appearance, race, gender and sexual orientation.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Silly Americans, laws are for poor people.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment contains identity attacks on Americans.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: More annoying drivel from plagiarist Wente.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment is unrelated and does not contain identity attacks.

Negative Examples.explanation: This comment should be non-identity-attack because it is not disrespectful to any groups.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: The Canadian gang of fools at the table.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be identity-attack because the comment contains identity attacks on Canadian.

Comment: This article's basic claim is a bit bizarre: It claims that by placing limits on jurisdictions to opt out of DST, time was synchronized across the country. The former, however, is unnecessary for the latter; in actual fact, the use or non-use of DST has nothing to do with clock synchronization, as long as basic rules are put in place to make sure contiguous populations generally observe the same rules (as in, for example, Indiana's old rule where the Central Time part of the state observed DST, but not the Eastern Time part).

Comment: "There are far more dual income families today than in the 1970's."
============

Actually somewhat surprisingly there AREN'T many more dual-income households than there were in the 1970's.

The reason is quite simple: there are a lot more single people living on their own and single-parent families than there used to be.  If you were to ONLY look at the two-parent families then yes, a much larger proportion of them are dual income families.  However two-parent families make up a much smaller proportion of all households than they did in the 1970's, so when looking at all households the number of dual-income households hasn't changed much.

Comment: Well I see that a lot of posters have had their comments removed. And why? In a nutshell the problem we have is that in Canada we do not have free speech, even on Canada Day. Do not for one minute think that you have the same right to free speech that our American neighbours have protected by the First Amendment to the United States Constitution. Oh, what is this you say? We have Freedom of Expression Guaranteed by the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. NO you do not and why not? Well...

Trudeau senior was very cagey when he crafted that Charter. Sure section 2(b) of the Charter says "Freedom of thought, belief, opinion and expression..." but the old curmudgeon stuck in a clause that could take it away. That's right, the infamous weasel clause or section 1. Believe me the Americans never would have stood for that but we had that bamboozled right by us.  

If it could possibly hurt someones feelings the Courts use section 1 to zap it just like the Globe censors do.

Comment: Alexandra,
I have long tried to be an "independent," although I will readily admit that in terms of politics, I lean right, while in terms of social justice, I lean a bit to the left.  Those ARE my biases, and I don't think I've ever tried to hide them.  My wife and I have tended to be TV news junkies for a while now, and I HAVE seen a lot of what I will call "screaming."

I don't profess to be a constitutional scholar, but while I law school I DID tend to load up on constitutional law classes.  So I DO find it more than a little amusing to listen to the punditry and commentators talk about the constitution and what it does/does not say.

As to "screaming," all you need to is to tune into the evening news to see it, daily.  My point is that we need to get past that, and back to respectful disagreement in society.    

As to the nuclear option, much ado about nothing.  The "60-vote" threshold is a senate rule, relatively recent at that.  It required civility in Congress to work.

Comment: I hate to disagree with you, but you overlooked the federal income tax implication of receiving a dividend. We pay 15-35% to the feds, so a $2k dividend is only worth $1,300-1,700 to residents. 

So if your income tax was, say $4,000, and the dividend was $2,000, your federal tax benefit of the state tax would be a reduction of taxable income of $2,000, or net cash to you of $300-700. 

But, we would have to hire 80-100 new state employees to implement, collect and audit those tax returns. At an average of $70k/year plus 50% benefit burden, that is $8-10million per year in added costs. That, of course, is in addition to the 80-100 currently employed for the PFD program. 

You want to cut state government? Do away with the dividend, it is the largest single expenditure of the state's budget.

Comment: During a recent BOG testimony it was revealed that moose will not eat willows high or higher in tannin. That is why you will see moose eat some willows and avoid seemingly the same willow plant elsewhere. Not all willow is considered edible by moose and they know which ones they are. Interesting. However the statement "Both plants contain bacteria-killing tannins that disrupt fermentation without interfering with a cow's digestion." is flat wrong. The way a ruminants digestion system works is by fermentation and disrupting it or killing the bacteria is disrupting the process. Bacteria do the work and in turn the ruminants digest the bacteria particularly for protein. Dead bacteria do not reproduce and fewer bacteria to digest means less protein and that means less meat per feed input. Simple as that.

Comment: It is a blessing that in the US, beyond the Constitution, federal statutes provide for strict scrutiny in any attempts to advance a compelling government interest & require the least restrictive means practicable where matters of conscience are at stake. Now, of course, we cannot entirely avoid remote material cooperation with perceived evils in pluralistic societies, but religious freedom statutes do prescribe such avoidance to a most reasonable extent!

For example, if there exists a less restrictive means than signing an opt-out form to conscientiously object to a mandate, the onus is on the government to provide it. But we can trivialize our own moral philosophical distinctions, e.g. remote material cooperation, by pressing such claims too far, especially with hyperbolic cries of religious persecution, e.g. of Little Sisters of the Poor. More tragically, we then trivialize the real religious persecution taking place elsewhere across the globe.

Comment: Another issue that has been ignored is the unfair or inequitable treatment of homeowners and other asset owners regarding income on capital gains. In a logical world all income would be taxed the same. This would include salaries, capital gains on home sales, professional income, and capital gains on stock or other asset sales. This would go a long way to take some of the heat out of the real estate and stock markets, as both are inflated assets (aka bubbles). But if one wishes to maintain the capital gains exemptions on homes, it could be made more equal if it was a once in a lifetime thing and it was only for the average value of a home in Canada at the time of the claim, so the playing field was more equitable or equal. Increasing the holding period from one year to a five year minimum, with the holder being required to have paid personal income tax in Canada for that period might also help. These are all understandable and addressable issues.

Comment: Pretty basic idea here.  A criminal is someone who commits a crime.  A crime is violation of a specific criminal statute.  There are requirements imposed by law that are not criminal.

Failure to register your vehicle is actually a civil requirement.  In Colorado, failure to register can result in a late fee of up to $100.  Operating a vehicle with expired registration is an infraction, not a crime.  You can't be jailed for driving with expired tags.

Comment: Dave writes: “economists expect the central bank to tread cautiously on the inflation front, likely stressing that the January surge above the bank’s target was the result of a relatively short-term spike in gasoline costs, and not a sign of building underlying inflationary pressures in the economy.” Good luck to them trying to show that this was all about gasoline. Purchase of passenger vehicles was up by 3.8%, homeowners’ replacement cost (i.e. dwelling prices) by 4.3%, natural gas by 15.6%. And there will almost certainly be governments imposing additional costs in 2017 whatever the potential output gap. Often there is no difference between the CPIX and CPIXV8 rates of inflation, but in January the CPIX inflation rate was 1.7% versus 1.8% for CPIXV8, the difference being hikes in indirect taxes.

Comment: The Seward Highway is an outdated two-lane country road traversed by everything from motorcycles, tandem tractor trailers and slow moving recreational vehicles.  There are ridiculously blind sections, dangerous three lane passing zones, ice in winter, falling rocks, stopping for dangerous left turns and mindless people walking across the highway. It is difficult to conceive how a more dangerous highway might be constructed.  The highway might be acceptable in rural Montana, but as the only highway south of Anchorage it is dangerously inadequate. Those who believe more traffic enforcement is the answer are living in a fool’s world. Enforcement is no substitute for a dangerously constructed highway. Just how low a speed limit would make the highway safe? It certainly isn’t the widely ignored 55 mph, and what's so special about 55 mph. Make it lower and it will only mean even more senseless speeding tickets. That the highway remains essentially unchanged for decades is disgraceful.

Comment: The real number to look at is did wind power lower energy costs in rural Alaska?  My understanding is that the actual savings, even with totally tax payer funded wind facilities, have been negligible.  This is due to expensive switch gear, maintenance costs, the fact that if the wind isn't blowing hard enough, you still have to run the diesel generator.  On a global level if you want to look at how the "green economy" works for the middle class, just goggle Spain green economy.  It turned out to be a disaster with unemployment rising to 27% (50% for youth) and almost double energy costs.  Also left the government in massive debt and loans left unpaid.  They had to abandon it.  There are a few places like kodiak where it is also tied into hydro where it will work.  Almost everywhere else?  Not so much.  Its important that we be real about this.

"Homosexual persons, as human persons, have the same rights as all persons including the right of not being treated in a manner which offends their personal dignity (cf. no. 10). Among other rights, all persons have the right to work, to housing, etc. Nevertheless, these rights are not absolute. They can be legitimately limited for objectively disordered external conduct. This is sometimes not only licit but obligatory. This would obtain moreover not only in the case of culpable behavior but even in the case of actions of the physically or mentally ill. Comment: That's obviously not a relevant comparison.  Harvard hardly needs athletics to promote itself these days, given that it's funded by a $36 billion endowment (the world's largest for an academic institution) and has had 381 years to establish itself as the country's preeminent university.  However it's notable that Harvard won 9 college football national championships between 1890 and 1919, when it was cementing itself in the national consciousness as the elite among elites.  Yale won 27 national football titles between 1872 and 1927, and Princeton won 28 between 1869 and 1950.

Setting aside ancient history, the relevant question is how effectively Alabama or Oklahoma or (more recently) Oregon would market themselves without football?  Or Kansas or Kentucky or North Carolina without basketball?  These are all good schools but they can't rely solely on an elite academic reputation to keep their names visible in the national media.  Athletics helps them do that, year in and year out.

Comment: Judge Hargreaves is telling it like it is.  Judges are charged with being fair, rational, and impartial.  District attorneys are charged with and rewarded for the most convictions/guilty pleas they can obtain.  Stripping judges of sentencing discretion placed enormous power in the hands of district attorney's which they typically use to force guilty pleas.  The media virtually never presents interviews with those who are forced to take a plea bargain so that we the public rarely get a perspective of what's actually going on.  In fact, the media typically reports guilty pleas with no discussion of the plea bargain involved.  Since DA's control the charge, they control the sentence.  For simple actions, the DA will level maybe ten charges.  Total sentence if convicted by a jury would typically be life.  Thus the dude must plead guilty when the DA offers to reduce charges regardless of true guilt because his defense attorney will tell him juries favor the DA.

Comment: I do not know if CETA is a good deal for everyday Canadians or Europeans. On that front my confidence is guarded. I am less guarded in asserting that it is good for multinational corporations and the elites on both sides. Having said that, at least this is a deal between countries of similar economic and social development that makes for a better chance of fairness and less abrupt dislocations for everyday citizens. On this level the deal presents less risk. A similar deal is not possible with less developed regions of the world. There an overwhelming proportion of benefit will accrue to multinational corporations and elites, and an overwhelming proportion of the dislocation risk would be borne by everyday citizens. This is where Trudeau's zeal for broad free trade is bad. Probably "bad" out of naivete or ignorance than malicious intent or deliberately choosing elites and multinational corporations over everyday citizens. This is why "populism had taken hold and in my view rightly so.

With the support of these funders and the great work of Steve and the rest of the PEPP team, no Hawaiian plant species has gone extinct since PEPP's founding. In fact, several species thought to have been extinct have been discovered!
Please visit pepphi.org for more information.

Comment: Probably not.  The commercial fishing season was moved back to July 1 long before this. There may have been some 60' personal use nets (the regs change a lot, I can't remember what was used when), but their impact on kings was negligible.  

But if your point is that commercial fishing can't be solely blamed for the poor state of the fishery today, you are correct.  Both runs were healthy in the 80's; both are a mess now. Pointing a finger at commercial fishing ignores the fact that there's been no commercial effort on the first run since the 70's, yet it's arguably in worse shape than the second run (which has been commercially fished every year).   

Rebuilding and preserving the runs should be a priority, based on a comprehensive review of spawning and rearing habitat, water quality, user group pressure/harvest efficiency, etc. Anyone proclaiming that eliminating a single user group will solve the problem (KRSA, Joe Connors) is using your gullibility to line their own pockets.

Additionally, having a provider with no DEA certification prescribing medications for the relief of  substance withdrawal is not acceptable practice. The medications used to treat alcohol withdrawal, in particular,  have ALWAYS required it.

Comment: There are a number of reason why this proposal is not practical.  To anchor the USS Kitty Hawk (CVA/CV 63) off shore, there are the collision regulations (COLREGS) to be considered which would prohibit the anchoring a ship in shipping lanes.  That would also mean that the navigation lights would have to be active.  Furthermore, the ship then would have to be manned with a crew to ensure that all landing cables are safe and not in danger of breaking.  I have seen the results of a landing cable snapping with loss of life and limbs and it is not pretty.  To have crew on board would means that they have to be fed, etc.  
While the idea appears to be good, it is not practical.  
Being a former crewmember on the USS Kitty Hawk during the late 1960's, I would like to endorse this concept but a better use would be as a maritime museum.

Comment: "The Structure of Scientific Revolutions, popularized the idea of “paradigm shift” in science, the way perception of the physical universe can be turned upside down by abrupt changes in world view...."  I know Dr. Kingwell is far better informed than I about philosophy, but I'm not sure he's doing Thomas Kuhn's book justice here, which I read more than once when I was younger and which actually to some extent informs my own world view. 

 Kuhn said that paradigms shift when, after a long period of time anomalies pile up about things that are considered fact (the earth is flat, or the center of the solary system, etc.).   Finally so many anomalies accumulate, that the paradigm shifts.  The shift is not actually abrupt, but can appear so.  

This kind of thing applies to social affairs and politics as well.  Revolutions when they break out may same sudden and shocking, but the build up may have been going on for a long long time.  Suddenly the world becomes  a secular place.  And so on.

Comment: Sludge takes a long time to build up - encouraged by not changing oil and filter at the recommended intervals. Turbos are especially sensitive. The sludge in the pipe would mislead the oil pressure gauge by causing & continuing to indicate high oil pressure when in fact insufficient oil was reaching the turbo bearings.
Oil and filter changes well within recommended intervals are cheap engine insurance. Also buy oil filters from a reputable source such as FRAM - not the OEM versions which I have found to be largely ineffective.
I do my own to ensure proper high quality oil and efficient filters - saves tiome and money. Engines should last > 250,000Km these days without burning oil or loosing pressure.
The vehicle was a failure time bomb waiting to go off !

Comment: I injured my shoulder 4 months ago.  Did physio for a while to little effect.  So I met with my doctor who recommended an ultrasound, which I duly booked - in October.  Booking involved a fax, and a 3 week wait, with an eventual phone call.  My appointment is in February!  Sweet.  Problem is, I can't play sports, hardly exercise, can only sleep on one side.  

One day I found out that I could get an ultrasound on the Quebec side for $225.  So I called them, got it the next day.  2 days later my doctor called to give me some good news.  I restarted physio with a better understanding of what I was dealing with, and things are slowly improving.

I'm going to cancel my February appointment so some other person - maybe someone without $225 - can take my spot.  Hopefully by then it won't hurt to pick up my kid.

This is what unionized medicine is doing to us in Ontario.

Comment: FWIW ... ransomware doesn't always look like an email from a friend.  I had a client who got a very authentic looking email that looked like it was from FedEx, clicked on the attachment which was supposed to be an invoice or other such innocuous document, but was actually a self-extracting ZIP file that loaded the virus then deleted the original file.

The virus does not immediately make itself known, but it was working in the background encrypting all the files.   Once its done, it will DELETE all the non-encrypted files, and all you're left with are files you cannot use without getting the decryption key.  The encryption key is self-generated by the virus, and the only person who can create the decryption key is the person who created the ransomware.

Comment: Part 1
In many cases, it is impossible to get legal status.  Family based-visas are limited to spouses, children, parents and siblings of US citizens and to spouses and unmarried children of permanent residents (green-card holders).  If someone does not have a qualifying relative, then this route is closed.  Nonimmigrant (ie temporary) visas are not available to those who are here without authorization.  Employment-based immigrant visas (those that permit adjustment of status to permanent resident) are  often difficult to obtain and expensive and require an employer who is willing to pay the costs (including attorney fees).  Getting such a visa petition approved does not permit one to remain here.  One must apply for and get permanent residence to remain.  If one is not in lawful status, one cannot apply for permanent residence in the US, but must leave the country to process abroad.  But if one has been present unlawfully for a year or more, one may not return for 10 years. 
Contd

Comment: One thing I would like to point out. 

Their business is inventing $1000 a month into 'mutual funds'. There is no information on what those particular Funds are or the purpose in their overall plan so it is difficult to judge if they are suitable or not. 

Here is something they may consider to help avoid taxes on gains in investments inside the corporation.  If a resident Canadian corporation invests in preferred shares of another resident Canadian corporation, the dividend income is not taxable to the receiving corporation.  This is not the case with interest income and may not be the case with capital gains.  (I am not sure about the CG issue)

It might make more sense for them to invest profits inside their corporation directly into prefs of other Canadian corporations.  There could be tax savings here. 

They really should have some professional help with these issues.  It does not seem like this is currently the case.

Comment: I'm confused by my reading about the US estate tax repeal.

I understand estate tax to mean beneficiaries being taxed on inheritance received. It that right?

But I also understand the this so-called "death tax" repeal with create a new tax shelter for the living -- capital gains earned while alive are not taxed at death, either in the hands of the estate or in the hand of beneficiaries. Properties and stocks subject to capital gains can be bequeathed without the estate paying the outstanding tax  increased value, and the the deemed purchase value of these properties/stocks in the hands of  beneficiaries is reset to current market value. Is that correct?

In Canada we have never had an estate tax, and we have a simple rule that ensures all taxes on income earned while alive is paid--at death, anything subject to capital gains is deemed to have been sold on the day of death, the the deceased's terminal tax return (not the estate return) is taxed on the gains from those deemed sales.

Comment: I would agree that calling non-paying renters "deadbeat" is unfair. But I also agree that most evictions are due to non-payment for whatever difficulties the tenant is going through. In my observation, most judges are already quite sympathetic to the tenant and often give tenant ample time to move out on the writ of execution at the landlord's expense. If the tenant starts to lawyer up in the most black-and-white eviction cases, the landlord may have to raise the criteria for tenant qualifications and increase security deposit amount to buffer themselves in prolonged legal process. I am not sure this is good for either the tenant or the landlord. Only lawyers will benefit from the situation.

It's not the field per se but more about the feeling of self-accomplishment and pride in working within communities.
I remember back in the 90's a woman in Regina got upset about seeing kids during school lunch breaks hanging around and not being provided a proper lunch.  Instead of demanding from Gov't, she went to various local business and asked for a little assistance to get food that she would prepare for the kids every day. Pride in accomplishment goes a long way.

Comment: Rains arrival almost always puts out the big persistent forest fires as it has for millennia.

The extinguishing rain highlights the wastefulness of the hundreds of millions of dollars spent annually on the firefighting air force. The use of enormously expensive helicopters and tankers does little to quench big blazes other than provide media fodder. The money would be better spent on the ground troops who ignite the back burns and clear the fuels. I say this having fought fire and worked on preventive fuel reduction projects.

By "preventive fuel reduction projects" I don't mean logging. I refer to clearing small understory trees, slash, brush, and grasses down to bare soil beneath the forest canopy. Especially around house perimeters, property lines, and on both sides of forest roads. Creating and maintaining this condition is what helped save my cabin in the midst of the Biscuit Fire.

After spending over $30,000,000 to mostly watch Biscuit burn, it was the rain that put it out!

Comment: Understanding the current economy is fairly straight forward and doesn't depend on 'the gods of economics' like Keynes.

Then they discovered 'globalization' which allowed them to set up companies around the world and have the corporate tax paid there (at much lower levels) with the profits becoming income to the rich (who didn't pay much on it). Comment: Speed humps belong in the purview of Traffic Engineering, period.  AFD has no business having veto power over them; that authority was slid through by incorporating the latest International Fire Code as Muni Code. High speed neighborhood traffic is one if not the single most consistent issue raised by citizens and has been for the 25+ years of my Community Council service. I served on the commission that developed the "toolbox" for Traffic Calming; the speed hump emerged as the single most effective bang for the buck item in it.  Agencies screamed and wrung their hands with none of the "issues" ever amounting to much if anything. Graders have a float selection for winter, first responders either slow a bit or take more appropriate routes in the first place.  Speed humps tamed my street from a raceway with vehicles documented at 51 mph to the current average appropriate to 25 mph residential streets. On duty 24X365, they never rest nor give up.

Comment: Hi Rage,
The selection you shared doesn't contradict what I've said. To start, my statement was about sex offenders generally, not just child molesters. The numbers you're providing are regarding child molesters in particular. 
Further, if you look at the line directly before the line you've cited, it reads: "The researchers reported that 5.1 percent of the child molesters in the study were rearrested for a new sex crime within 3 years of their release..." meaning that 95% of child molesters were not re-arrested for a new sex crime. 
The numbers you have cited have to do with comparing subsets of child molesters: those with more than one prior arrest versus those with only one type of prior arrest. 
Lastly, regarding the bit that starts with "As might be expected...", what they're saying here is that child molesters were more likely than other types of sex offenders to commit a sex crime against a child after release, which is different than re-offense rates.
Does that clear things up?

Comment: Canada 2017
-
The emperor took off all his clothes, and the swindlers pretended to dress him, piece by piece, with the new ones that were to be fitted. Then the emperor turned and looked into the mirror.
-
"Goodness, they suit you well! What a wonderful fit!" they all said. "What a pattern! What colors! Such luxurious clothes!"
-
Yes, I am ready!" said the emperor. "Don't they fit well?" He turned once again toward the mirror, because it had to appear as though he were admiring himself in all his glory.
-
The chamberlains who were to carry the train held their hands just above the floor as if they were picking up the train. As they walked they pretended to hold the train high, for they could not let anyone notice that they could see nothing.
-
"But he doesn't have anything on!" said a small child.
-
The emperor shuddered, for he knew that they were right, but he carried himself even more proudly, and the chamberlains walked along behind carrying the train that wasn't there.
-

Comment: There we go with the "strawman" arguments. Nemo suggests I believe medicare was threatened by NAFTA which I don't. Current public programs are effectively grandfathered with the NAFTA and CETA process. It is only new programs that can trigger the compensation suits. So if free universal pharmacare insurance is brought in by government that replaces the private insurers, I'll bet any money that the private insurers of extended health programs will sue under NAFTA (and now CETA) for their lost markets. Similarly when Ontario was considering bringing in a BC style government auto insurance, it was the threat of NAFTA lawsuits from private auto insurers that stopped Ontario from considering it further. BC can keep its public auto insurer but no one else can set it up without compensating private insurers under NAFTA or CETA. Now the European corporations can sue us as well.

Comment: IRT Justin Tanoue:  I agree that the Japanese could probably have built our rail quicker, better, and with greater quality, but...that's about it.  As far as comparing them to our situation, it's apples and oranges.  Rail works in Japan because of their huge network of spikes leading to the main lines and the fact that most major cities were already pre-planned with rail being the primary source of transportation.  Similarly, with the Metro in Washington, DC and the New York subway systems.  Plus, the population base in all these areas is huge.  In our case, the population base that will likely use the rail numbers in the thousands (if we are lucky), and it is a Point A to Point B system.  There will still be a great need for buses which, if that is the case, we should have simply enhanced the bus system.

The male, usually the strongest and most aggressive one, fights the other males for breeding rights, and the female is the leader.  If a rancher shoots either Alpha then the pack falls into a lower state of order, and breeding diminishes for a while.  When Fish and Feathers employees do the culling, or the public is given permits, there is usually no distinction made between the Alpha's and other wolves.  Were clear photos made (remotely activated Go Pro's) available, the Alpha's could be identified, and spared.  A good reason for sparing the Alphas is that wolves are intelligent enough to understand that hunting around certain areas almost always gets some of their pack killed, and the Alphas then display avoidance behavior.  A lot of the culling takes place in the deep woods, where the Alphas can't get any clue as to why they are being killed, nor where there may be "safe" areas.

Comment: I believe, at least in the South Willamette Special Area Zone, the housing forms that require less land, can be owned, and which at least some of the market would find attractive are identified in the following places:
1. The "Single Family Options" areas-- which maintains the density-levels allowed in the R1 zoning, but allows for additional types of housing in the form of group of small cottages or a courtyard house.
2. The "Single Family Options- Rowhouse allowed" which specifically adds 2-3 story townhouses to the mix.
3. The "Apartment/condo- Rowhouse Character Required" sub-zone, which allows 2-3 story buildings with a rowhouse character. 

Most of the areas where it is labeled as apartment/condo (w/out the rowhouse character) are either already zoned R-2 or 3, or are in the Metro Plan as medium or high density, and with the height limit decrease, high-rise apartments aren't much of an option. So it feels like identifying those forms is one of the main points of the SWSAZ.

All we understand about God and "divine revelation" is based on knowledge at the time the "revelation" was "discovered" and how we understand it was filtered through the culture of the person(s) trying to make sense of the unknowable mystery that is God. Comment: It's true that different therapies, pharmaceutical and otherwise, may have different rates of effectiveness. A science-based approach would see a doctor consider the potential effectiveness vs the potential risks and assign the most likely successful intervention.  The condition would then be monitored and the course of therapy altered if the desired outcomes were not being achieved in an adequate amount of time. No treatment is 100% effective or safe for everyone. But forgoing a treatment because it might not work or may have some risk, for a condition that has higher risk, is like refusing a life buoy to be thrown to you when you are in danger of drowning because there's a small chance it may hit you on the head and knock you out.

Comment: This issue is crystal clear, IF we understand how accounting works.

Discounts are not a taxable benefit unless their value is less than their book value to the company minus depreciation.

If the asset is perishable, and it is fully depreciated at the time of consumption it is not a taxable benefit.

A burger, for example, is fully depreciated by end of day. And therefore an employee eating it has no taxable benefit - as it would go in the garbage - proving it has zero value.

However, an employee getting a boat for free, the boat almost certainly has a book value to the employer.

For a boat manufacturer, it is the cost value of making it from raw materials, for everyone else it is the retail purchase value - regardless it is the book value - minus any depreciation on the asset.

If the burger maker gave the fully depreciated asset, it is not a taxable benefit. 
If they gave away a $100 gift card to be used to buy burgers, the transaction value is $100, as there is a $100 liability.

Comment: Taking Denver out would not be "real Colorado results". Last I checked, Denver is IN Colorado.  The Nationwide study is one of all cars registered in the state of Colorado who have Nationwide insurance AND whose owners have elected to use the monitors to reduce their insurance rates.  So there is, in theory, a proportional sample from all parts of the state.  Denver has the most drivers, so they have a high representation, but not an over-representation.  

And the results may be skewed because a lot of people who would bother with the monitors are people whose insurance rates went up, very possibly because they already have a ticket or two and/or and at-fault accident.  The best Nationwide drivers, whose rates have held steady because of no tickets or claims, likely aren't in the sample at all.

Comment: <<It's depressing and stressful to contemplate the church's complicity in support for Trump.>>

I was faced with this very predicament at Mass this morning.  The celebrant -- a good man, a good priest -- asserted that a Catholic could not vote for Hillary Clinton. To be fair, he did not mention Clinton's name and he did not recommend a vote for Donald Trump; but his meaning was unmistakable. I did something I haven't done in thirty years or more -- I left Mass after the homily because of the homily.  Already, I regret that I did -- and I'll probably confess it the next time I go to confession.  And I will discuss it with the priest-celebrant.  But this gets precisely to your point -- the church's ministers must find the language to promote Christian and Catholic teaching, and support the exercise of the voting franchise, without being complicit in the election of Donald Trump; indeed, without endorsing anyone.  The single issue approach fails; it leads to simplistic, false conclusions.

Comment: "Can I take that portion of my tax dollars and give it to an organization that I feel does a better job?"

I myself am not saying there is no place for government. Certainly I believe that the welfare of our children is to some degree the responsibility of all, thus I would not say that paying taxes for parts of government we may not agree with should be "optional".

I would also say that taxes to help educational institutions, fund security, courts, etc. is very necessary.

What gets me about "public school" and vouchers question is that we already DO THAT for kindergarten (tax deduction) and for higher education (the college fund 401k style tax free savings accounts).  

Why not have the same for secondary education?

Obviously - we could not change the system overnight (witness ObamaCare) so a good solution might be a voucher system that at least partially reimburses taxes paid by those whom are sending their kids to private schools and thus not stressing the public school system.

Comment: Good for you (seriously). However, we have a fundamental difference of opinion. An essential problem for C corporations right now is that these corporations have a fiduciary duty to increase value for shareholders. This has largely been interpreted as a reason to prioritize short term profit taking, even at the expense of long-term goals. Which means that C corps will push to decrease taxes, even if it robs them of their ability to compete internationally with companies that have access to better infrastructure and training of employees. So, yes, profit is good is capital can be used in all sorts of beneficial ways. But, like all things, there is a balance point where the marginal utility of new profit is less valuable than government investments. We apparently disagree on that balance point, which is fine.

I am happy to pay my taxes. But of course I want a general agreement and participation by all. I wouldn't ask you to forgo all government services if you want a smaller government.

Comment: It's a sad situation.

Full disclosure, I used to work in film and TV production.

What I learned is that Canadian broadcasters (and film distributors) couldn't care less about domestic content - at least in English Canada. French Canada is a different and  happier story. 

Canadian broadcasters have historically made their money by paying almost nothing for US shows and even substituting Canadian commercials on US cable channels. Comment: Biology is all about rates. Orange juice is little different than cola because the rate of fructose absorption from the gut is little different. Whole fruit is less problematic because digestion has to break apart plant cell walls to release the sugars, so the fructose rate is buffered. 

What matters is the rate fructose enters the liver. Depending on what else is occupying the liver at the time, the liver can harmlessly metabolize low rates of fructose into glucose or lactate, but when overwhelmed the liver metabolizes fructose into triglycerides (palmitic acid saturated fat), much of which gets put into VLDL particles with cholesterol for transport to cells. If the liver is yet still overwhelmed, triglyceride accumulates locally as liver fat, leading to insulin resistance in the liver and metabolic syndrome.

There is no significant difference between HFCS, table sugar, cane sugar or fruit sugar. They are all near 50% fructose when digested. (Lactose sugar has no fructose.)

Comment: Apart from all the opinionating about gay sex (EG not love but only sodomy), no one addresses the fact that most gay relationships that lead to marriage are, in fact, rooted profoundly in love, caring and respect. Also, much of the science of sexuality views sexuality on a continuum, ie, the idea of "normal" is now seen as inclusive of homosexuality. This is not to say that the vast majority of people in the world are not heterosexual. It means that the demonization of gays in the world that constantly derides gay people as morally bankrupt and yet to be respected, is an insult beyond the pale.

Comment: "These "white men" you speak of seem to have very limited experience of anyone other than themselves."

This is a very narrow-minded way of looking at the vast diversity of the people of the United States, a country that is great because of it's diversity, not in spite of it!

Comment: Thank you Mr. Manning. And to think that all along I thought the populist unrest was caused by political institutions, parties, media, corporations and a financial system that overwhelmingly serve the interests of business and the wealthy. Hence of course, the breathtaking rise over the past 30 years of economic inequality, social injustice and general hopelessness and desperation among ordinary citizens in western democracies. Now you have come along and straightened us out. It's not that. It's because our governments are not sufficiently pro-business and xenophobic. We need more Ayn Rand (the absolute pursuit of self-interest) and less wishy washy Canadian-ish-nish style of inclusive government for all people. Got it.

Comment: A tight ship? seems more like the "Kon Tiki". We will all be lucky if we make it to an island before it falls apart, the pieces washing up on an Asian shore like so much flotsam and jetsam. The economic corpse picked apart by the vultures of stable governments around the world.
